issues.description: The problem statement and the template define the service method addParent(Person person, Person parent) where the first parameter is the person (child) and the second is the parent. In the solution implementation the method signature uses the same parameter types but the parameter names are swapped (addParent(Person parent, Person person)) and the method body operates on the parameters according to those swapped names. This creates a semantic mismatch between the intended API (first arg = person/child, second arg = parent) and the solution implementation. It can confuse students who compare template, problem statement, and solution (or who read the solution tests and implementation), and may lead to incorrect behavior if the parameters are interpreted in the wrong order.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution's addParent method match the intended parameter ordering and semantics from the problem statement and template: declare it as addParent(Person person, Person parent) and implement the logic to operate on the first parameter as the child (i.e., check person.getParents().size(), add parent to person.getParents(), and save person). This keeps the API and semantics consistent across problem statement, template, controller calls, and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement and template expect the service method signature addParent(Person person, Person parent) (first parameter = the child/person being modified, second = the parent). In the solution implementation the parameter names are swapped in the method declaration (addParent(Person parent, Person person)), i.e., the declared parameter identifiers do not match the ordering/meaning described in the problem and shown in the template. This creates a mapping confusion: readers expect the first parameter to be the child and the second the parent, but the solution's parameter names suggest the opposite. Although the runtime method descriptor (Person, Person) is the same, the swapped parameter identifiers and their usage inside the solution implementation invert the conceptual roles and can mislead students when comparing problem requirements, template stubs, and the reference implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the parameter naming across artifacts so the conceptual roles are explicit and consistent. Prefer explicit names that reflect roles, e.g. change the solution method signature to: public Person addParent(Person person, Person parent) (or even better: public Person addParent(Person child, Person parent)) and update its body to use these names accordingly. Ensure the problem statement, template stub, and solution all use the same parameter names/order (child/person first, parent second) to avoid cognitive mapping overhead.
